prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As noted above, we need to resolve the line profile shape at high S/N to sort out and model blended lines. There is no data rate issue with these TDM spws.

We match the beam to approximately the known size of the ejecta from Cycle 0 Band 9 continuum observations, 0.8x0.4arcsec. This maximizes sensitivity for faint line detection. The entire remnant is <2arcsec across, so we don't need to recover any spatial information larger than that.

Predicted line strengths are based on NLTE modeling of existing Cycle 2 data, and are for the entire ejecta (see Figure in science justification). The brightest in these spw are: SiS 7-6 127GHz 15mJy ? 30SiO 3-2 127.1 GHz 4mJy 29SiO 3-2 128.7GHz 4mJy SO 4(3)-3(2) 138.2GHz 10mJy In addition there are several predicted lines of SO and SO2 about 1mJy in flux density.
However, the motivation for this Cycle 3 proposal is to confirm or deny some of the large ucnertainties in excitation and abundance still not well-constrained by the Cycle 2 data i.e. the lines could be fainter. The requested angular resolution is matched to the ejecta size, i.e. we expect about half of total line flux in each synthesized beam. So we request 0.2mJy/bm sensitivity to have a strong S/N>5 detection of even fainter lines We must resolve the shape of the line profile, to be able to distinguish between blended 2000 km/s wide lines, so request that sensitivity over 500 km/s spectral resolution.
The dust continuum flux density is extrapolated from our Cycle 0 data. Continuum detection in Band 4 is not a primary science driver, but we do expect to detect it, and it will be quite interesting to contrain the shape of both the dust and shocked ring SEDs.
As noted above, we need to resolve the line profile shape at high S/N to sort out and model blended lines. There is no data rate issue with these TDM spws.

We match the beam to approximately the known size of the ejecta from Cycle 0 Band 9 continuum observations, 0.8x0.4arcsec. This maximizes sensitivity for faint line detection. The entire remnant is <2arcsec across, so we don't need to recover any spatial information larger than that.

Predicted line strengths are based on NLTE modeling of existing Cycle 2 data, and are for the entire ejecta (see Figure in science justification). The brightest in these spw are: SO 3(3)-3(3) 129.1GHz 3mJy 28SiO 130.3 GHz 12 mJy SiS 8-7 145.2GHz 12mJy (half of the line) In addition there are several predicted lines of SO and SO2 about 1mJy in flux density.

The brightest in these spw are: SO2 5(1,5)-4(0,4) 135.7GHz 6mJy SiS 8-7 145.2GHz 12mJy ? (half of the line) CS 3-2 147GHz 3mJy In addition there are several predicted lines of SO and SO2 about 1mJy in flux density.

We match the beam to approximately the known size of the ejecta from Cycle-0 band9 continuum observations, 0.8x0.4 arcsec^2. This maximizes sensitivity for faint line detection. The entire remnant is < 2arcsec across, so we don't need to recover any spatial information lager than that.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our Cycle 0 observations discovered strong broad CO line emission from SN 1987A (Kamenetzky et al. 2013). Our Cycle 2 observations, which have so far covered part of Band 6, confirmed very strong broad SiO emission and produced probable detections of HCO+ and SO. We propose a new spectral survey of the 90-150 GHz spectrum of SN 1987A, along with coverage of a few selected Band 7 regions, all at 0.3 arscec resolution. The aim is to unambiguously measure at least two to three lines from each species, enabling density and temperatures to be estimated and the chemical processes in play to be diagnosed. The survey will include lines of 29SiO, 30SiO and 13CO, enabling isotope ratios, or upper limits, to be measured for a supernova for the first time, diagnosing nucleosynthetic processes. We found CO and SiO to to have different line profiles, implying different spatial distributions for these two species; our proposed observations should yield profiles for further molecules. Our total time request including calibrations is 6.3hr.
